Comments_List: Helped my intuition of the history of US elections and how they affect American institutions.
This class helped me evaluate the number of different lenses one can look through when evaluating national elections in the United States.

I learned so much about US politics -- I learned about the theories relating to US politics, causes for phenomena like midterm losses, and lots of empirical evidence about previous elections I didn't learn as much about in history courses.
It's David Mayhew. There are no weaknesses.

Strengths: Listening to Mayhew talk in class; free-flowing class discussion; freedom to choose what to write final and mid-term papers about
Weaknesses: Reading wasn't very challengingwould like to see more recent work published in top journals; free-flowing nature of class discussion sometimes went off the rails academically, though was nearly always interesting to listen to

The strength of the courses is the blend of classic texts with contemporary scholarship. The timing of the class enabled discussion of the Midterm elections and its results using previously discussed course concepts.

I think the one thing that could be improved would be requiring a research paper rather than a literature review for graduate students -- I feel that would help us develop our skills in not just understanding, but contributing to the body of work on American elections . 

The stregnths were a clear course syllabus which clearly surveyed major theories and phenomena in American elections, and Professor Mayhew's incredible depth of knowledge on the subject.
Definitely. If only to experience Mayhew's thinking and class talking, and to write papers that could be useful for later research and thinking.

I would (and have) recommended this class to other students. Learning about elections from Professor Mayhew was an invaluable experience. The blend of graduate and undergraduate students also created a helpful dynamic in the class, conducive for my learning.
